content.content: Let’s please keep this thread specific to the Events CU. Team members (as MKR holders) are by all means welcome to speak their mind - we encourage transparent communication, however this does not represent the official stance of Protocol Engineering. Unless otherwise stated, Protocol Engineering as a Core Unit remains focused on its mandate of technical work as requested by Maker Governance and is neutral on this topic. Likewise, as a CU we are not involved in informal groups, but individuals are free to participate as they see fit as long as it does not impact their CU contributions.

content.content: I think it depends on how you define those. Not to mention within DAO, unless we want to invite legal understanding outside, we should look at what is permissible within governance frameworks. For example, some might object to initiative to offboarding in a short time period. There’s no governance rule against proposing such initiative and therefore I also think it’s valid. Or anonymous accounts applying as delegates. There’s no rule against it either. In similar fashion, there’s no rule within Maker governance that explicitly states you can’t voice your opinion or work / help with other CUs or even interested upcoming CUs (like LOVE CU right now). Also, what exactly is personal gain. Financial gain? Reputation? Is CU talking with delegates to appeal their case also considered personal gain as CUs get the benefit? Thus, unless there’s a governance rule that explicitly prohibit it or their actions actively undermine core work, I think it’s fine or at least tolerable.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: wouter:  Especially because the role of PE is part of the critical infrastructure. It should remain neutral so that the political power struggles leave the functioning of the core protocol unaffected.   Feel like some context on how GovAlpha navigates this issue might be useful. We maintain neutrality as a Core Unit, and hold our facilitators to this mandate. This makes sense as they are “in charge” and tasked with bridging comms between the core unit and the broader community. However, we do not make any contributor to GovAlpha adhere to neutrality, provided they are clearly expressing their personal view and not that of the Core Units. It is possible this causes some confusion, but we think it’s an important feature for Core Units with neutrality mandates. The DAO is strengthened by knowledgeable parties being able to debate and provide their prospective on issues. If we slowly take away the ability of those working in the Core Units to be able to express their opinions we’re left with discourse lacking significant stakeholders.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: Probably not the best person to answer these inquires, given the neutrality mandate   so will leave most of these to someone else. But I think it’s fair to say the A in DAO is supposed to stand for something. Obviously representations can be problematic and should be viewed on a case by case basis, but there are plenty of gaps in CU mandates that most organizations find necessary. Things like marketing and recruitment are obvious gaps in our mandate coverage. The reality is someone has to be doing work outside of the passed mandates. If it’s community members, great! If it’s CU members they need to be ensuring their mandated work is covered, but after that they should feel just as welcome to contribute their time, provided they aren’t making false assertions about what they have been authorized/mandated to do.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: prose11:  … provided they are clearly expressing their personal view and not that of the Core Units.   So, saying “I’m a mandated actor” as justification for activity in an area that has nothing to do with the mandated role… that would be inappropriate and show a lack of appreciation for that separation of the two roles? Another thing is the usage of the official forum account with badge. If the hobby next to the official role has gone to such extents, wouldn’t it be appropriate to use a different account? Back at the Foundation we were very careful to always clarify if we were talking in personal capacity and make that distinction clear. The DAO doesn’t have to be the same, but for me it’s pretty obvious that there is no distinction made. The theoretical rule is just held up as a justification to keep using one role to support the other. The exact opposite of careful disclosure and separation of the two. I’m assuming this is not in bad faith. But in reality it can be deceitful and we need to be careful. So I suggest we seriously show some effort to avoid the most obvious confusions.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: (I’m representing my own opinions and not those of DICU) @wouter, yes, I agree that CU members should generally focus on the tasks at hand. I understand the sentiment of wanting to differentiate between someone’s role within their Core Unit and their broader impact within the community. However, I feel this concept is quite reductive given our organisational model (DAO). I believe that the multifaceted aspects of CU members are a unique reason why people choose to work at a DAO instead of a corporation. I would even argue it’s our unique competitive advantage. In the opposite scenario would have only a few selected individuals weighing in on matters (even if they are “political”) while the rest are in their respective silos. I myself have not been vocal in the forum. Still, I sincerely appreciate the people who are, whether or not their opinions align with my personal views. I’m concerned about the path you are opening here, as I feel it limits the contribution of self-motivated contributors. I’ll offer my own set of leading questions:  Whose role is compatible with “political ambitions”? Is SES in a unique position to do so? Should PE abstain from any “political” discussions? Even those that may affect the core functioning of the protocol? Why are these ambitions “unbounded”? Should this word be interpreted negatively?  Lately, I’ve been reconsidering whether or not I should be more vocal with personal views in public. My main fear has been that in voicing my opinions, I may negatively affect the work we do at DICU. I worry it will affect the great people I work with and, ultimately, the community I serve. Given the reactions to this and similar topics in the forum as of late, I feel my fears might be true. I want to see Maker and everyone involved thrive together.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: 17 posts were split to a new topic: A Large Complex DAO: reducing the human footprint

Difficult to respond here because of the lack of clarity of discussion except to make the following comments. I have seen on-line communities decimated by users having multiple accounts.  Like one malicious actor could use like 3-5 accounts to basically set up some premise, have another vehemently attack, and then the other couple support varying points of view ALL to just to try to get attention to themselves by the community.   These people would purposely pick divisive issues and lay them out in some inflammatory way to satisfy their own ambitions (need for attention, desire to attack the community generally, or ??) The idea that anyone ‘is neutral’ I think is incorrect.  We all have inherent biases and predilections and I find it better when individuals simply come forward with these vs. endeavoring to present this ‘I am neutral’ kind of view.   As soon as I hear this from anyone I want to run because I know they probably are NOT going  to actualy be able to entertain ‘objective views’ because they are already ‘subjectively neutral’. So in reality here there are multiple issues.  Multiple accounts with same users, and this idea of of objective neutrality.  Both of these create numerous obstacles when it comes to communicating effectively, and generally dilute the ability to have constructive dialogue. In the end this is a tricky discussion because one has to not just subjectively disclose our non-neutrality, but then also manage debates and discussions with others who also are non-neutral and decidedly on other sides of important topics.   Healthy vs. unhealthy debate is a real issue, just as healthy vs. unhealthy discussion is.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: Okay. Trying to understand clearly. Was the group performing operations and “picking up slack” you operating as a PE mandated actor or informally? There seems to be two things going on:  a group performing ongoing business operations on behalf of makerdao and representing the DAO in transactions, and a group planning a new governance and business structure for Maker.  These groups are composed of seemingly the same people This ops group asked for this privilege and approach be formally codified their role  (task force) and the signs from the DAO so far has been to resoundingly reject that structure and your request. Those activities and that structure should then immediately cease until a different interim structure can be approved. Can you please disclose who this above group is? Is this simply the task force group? Who is different across the task force vs this “informal group” redesigning the DAO structure. As you can imagine, the concern is there is no clear boundary to warrant the claim of it being “informal.” On the other hand, this “informal group” is meeting in private with VCs to put together a vision and business strategy that is not being publicly disclosed or including other relevant core unit members and MKR holders in the process. This is a transparency problem as you can imagine. Unfortunately, it seems like the same people are part of both groups. Hence, the cause for concern. All or most of these parties in the informal group are also contracted as mandated actors by the DAO and engaging collectively in private with no transparency. This activity is allegedly done as informal meetings because of the gross ethical violations it otherwise presents. I think if you can just lay out transparently what has happened and who you are meeting with, why, and when, as well as the substance of the discussions it would help your credibility. Suggesting these meetings are informal, but that they involve cross core unit member coordination, business activity, and are directly relevant to different lines of business and involve only a subset of MKR stakeholders is tenuous at best…
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: (I’m a contributor to the risk core unit and recognized delegate but not a facilitator, not sure where I land with respect to “mandated actor” label. I’m speaking on my own behalf and not representing the views of delegators or the risk core unit) I’d like to share a quick anecdote from recent experience. I’ve been a Cosmos ecosystem enjoyer since early 2021, and deepened my participation after Osmosis DEX launched in June 2021. When DAI bridging to Cosmos became available earlier this year I was the first liquidity provider for both Gravity Bridge and Axelar Bridge DAI in the Cosmos, committing over 20k personal capital along with several thousand in fees for pool deployment. I successfully advocated (in a personal capacity) to add support for DAI pairs to Osmosis router and incentives schemes in the aftermath of Terra UST collapse (when the default course of action was to support just USDC). The OSMO/axlDAI LP now holds over $4 million TVL which is sufficient to make DAI a viable stablecoin and bridge asset within the Cosmos ecosystem. And there is an opportunity to expand DAI support to other platforms like Junoswap and Crescent DEX (which currently only support USDC). I didn’t commit to actions on behalf of MakerDAO, internally discuss with other contributors, or use any Maker resources. But neither did I ask permission from the DAO to engage in discussions with 3rd parties. If MKR holders insist on contributors strictly adhering to narrowly defined mandates and not taking any other initiative to ensure “political neutrality”, I don’t think they will be pleased with the results (missed opportunities and declining market share). It is neither healthy nor sustainable for an organization to demand contributors should be “seen but not heard”.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: monet-supply:  I didn’t commit to actions on behalf of MakerDAO, internally discuss with other contributors, or use any Maker resources. But neither did I ask permission from the DAO to engage in discussions with 3rd parties. If MKR holders insist on contributors strictly adhering to narrowly defined mandates and not taking any other initiative to ensure “political neutrality”,   Monet, Thanks for the response here. The point here is that you did not collude and withhold information from the community, other MKR holders, or your peers. You had integrity in your interactions.This is a great point to discuss. Integrity as a Core Hiring Criterion Rather than narrowly define mandates, etc, Maker would be best to have a clear vision and strong leadership at the core unit facilitator level in addition to a system of checks and balances. The facilitators are tasked with hiring talent with strong ethical and moral foundations and the ability to help them deliver on the vision. When deceit happens, trust is weakened. Trust in a decentralized workforce is more important than a centralized workforce, since generally, core units are entrusted with more autonomy and fewer checks and balances than a standard hierarchy. Trust Requires Integrity The primary criticism of this “growth task force group” is that they have been deceitful in their actions. Deceit can come as either telling outright lies, or withholding relevant information. When trust is broken, the damage is often irreparable. The core units are entrusted to act in the best interest of the protocol and MKR holders at large. Yet, a portion of individual contributors colluded to act in what appears to be their own interest and withheld their engagements with large MKR holder from other MKR holders. They also withheld this information from their core unit peers, their core unit facilitators, and from the community at large. Growth Task force: Unofficially Official then turned "informal community members" The task force notes above they are operating as a stop gap official operations unit for Maker. After some time, they felt it necessary to disclose their activities beyond their mandates and ask for their new privileges to be explicitly codified and expanded in an MIP. What was not disclosed at that time was that they had been having numerous discussions with large MKR whales to redesign governance and remove checks and balances. They colluded to design and create a new centralized hierarchy that places them in the position of an executive committee, above their peers and possibly to the detriment of MKR holders. Again, this information was withheld from other core units, MKR holders, and the community. When it was clear the task force would be rejected. The narrative changed from the group as an executive operations unit to being “informal” community members. This is again deceit because it fails to acknowledge what they themselves admitted:   their previous and ongoing role as a Maker “operations” unit and their current individual contributor roles which are paid. An individual contributor role comes with expectations of transparency.  (c.f. tweet) You only live once: Integrity or not, you decide. In the end, governance will not be able to defend against those who are willing to violate ethical boundaries for personal gain. This is an unfortunate reality. As Wouter noted above, what we can do is build systems that allow for discourse more openly. This helps to make these violations more clear and hopefully avoid back door centralization.  Right now, the lack of a system allows for plausible deniability, and the ability to claim business discussions are “informal” and need not be disclosed to the community and peers. The community is generally not this gullible. Maker has legs: Why break the ethos that gave it success? Designing appropriate transparent structures can create alleviate the operational inefficiencies that led to centralization. We can avoid the loss of trust within the workforce; we need not slap a centralized hierarchy on a decentralized protocol and call it a day. It would be best to take a long and honest look at the two proposed structures, including the fact that Maker is a decentralized protocol that requires decentralization to maintain its resilience. Many of the core team have been here for a long time, and together with those before them, designed and produced the most resilient project on Ethereum. All of these individuals are geniuses. Maybe we should ask them what centralization or decentralization means for the protocol? It would make sense to move slowly and be weary of a new guard throwing this ethos to the wind in pursuit of short term profit and control. The old guard and ethos has delivered to us the most successful project on Ethereum. What has this other group produced to inspire confidence in their plan to centralize? This is a community. Not a corporation.
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.
